docs.lead_paragraph: Federal health officials are strongly reaffirming their recommendation that people over 50 undergo routine screening for colorectal cancer. In a report being published today in The Annals of Internal Medicine, the United States Preventive Services Task Force, a medical advisory group that helps set government policy, said doctors should continue performing the tests. The task force found that they were not only valuable in reducing deaths from colorectal cancer but also cost-effective.
docs.abstract: US Preventive Services Task Force, reporting in Annals of Internal Medicine, reaffirm recommendation that people over 50 undergo routine colorectal cancer screenings; take no position on which of several screening methods should be used; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Federal health officials are strongly reaffirming their recommendation that people over 50 undergo routine screening for colorectal cancer.    In a report being published today in The Annals of Internal Medicine, the United States Preventive Services...

docs.lead_paragraph: In theory, AIDS is preventable and treatable. But in reality, AIDS has spread so rapidly it rivals the worst epidemics in history. AIDS has killed more than 20 million people since 1981, when the first cases were discovered in the United States. Today, 40 million people live with H.I.V., the AIDS virus, and most are doomed to die for lack of the powerful combinations of drugs that can control the infection. And because these people lack access to the blood test that can tell if they are H.I.V. infected, they may unwittingly transmit the virus to another 45 million people by 2010.

headline.main: The Urgent Search for an AIDS Plan

docs.abstract: Article on 14th International AIDS Conference in Barcelona, Spain; notes AIDS has killed more than 20 million people since 1981, 40 million people live with HIV virus and another 45 million are expected to contract disease by 2010, making it one of worst epidemics in history; experts disagree on whether funding should focus on prevention or treating those already infected; photos (M)
docs.snippet: In theory, AIDS is preventable and treatable. But in reality, AIDS has spread so rapidly it rivals the worst epidemics in history.    AIDS has killed more than 20 million people since 1981, when the first cases were discovered in the United States....

docs.lead_paragraph: It was the morning of March 29 -- Good Friday, Michael Kress remembers -- when he entered the bedroom of his 14-year-old son, Timmy, to wake him for school. Mr. Kress found Timmy on the floor. He yelled for his wife to dial 911, and he tried cardiopulmonary resuscitation. But Timmy had been dead for several hours.

headline.main: A Silent Killer Strikes The Hearts of the Young

docs.abstract: Article on hypertrophic cardiomyopathy, disorder in which growth of heart muscle is excessive and sometimes blocks flow of blood to aorta; University of California study finds that about half of cases may be at least partly attributed to genetic mutation (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: Many parents look askance at flavored milk, concerned that the last thing their children need is more sugar. But a recent study suggests that those boxes of orange, vanilla and chocolate milk may be part of a solution to a serious nutritional problem. ''We have a calcium crisis,'' said the lead author of the study, Dr. Rachel K. Johnson of the University of Vermont. ''Nine out of 10 teenage girls and 7 out of 10 teenage boys in the U.S. are not meeting their calcium recommendations.'' Later, the researchers said in The Journal of The American Dietetic Association, many of the subjects may face serious bone problems.
docs.abstract: University of Vermont researchers, reporting in Journal of The American Dietetic Assn, conclude that flavored milk, which contains calcium and sugar, is nutritionally better for children than soft drinks and sugar-sweetened fruit drinks; drawing (M)
docs.snippet: Many parents look askance at flavored milk, concerned that the last thing their children need is more sugar. But a recent study suggests that those boxes of orange, vanilla and chocolate milk may be part of a solution to a serious nutritional...

docs.lead_paragraph: When I was growing up, eating out or taking out was a special event. Now for ever-growing millions of Americans, restaurant-prepared food has become a way of life. And it shows -- on the scale and around the waistline. But even for those who manage to maintain a reasonably normal weight on restaurant fare, there is the chance that hidden health damage is occurring.

headline.main: How to Eat Out Without Tipping the Scales

docs.abstract: Jane Brody Personal Health column on new book, Restaurant Confidential by Center for Science in the Public Interest executive director Michael F Jacobson and center dietitian Jayne Hurley; offers suggestions from book for eating out more healthfully; chart (M)

keywords.value: CENTER FOR SCIENCE IN THE PUBLIC INTEREST

docs.lead_paragraph: For four years, Luis had kept his H.I.V. in check. For him, that meant remembering to take three different antiviral medicines at various times throughout the day, 10 pills in all. One of these, taken three times a day on an empty stomach, required Luis to drink extra water every day to avoid developing kidney stones, a known side effect of the medication.

headline.main: Improved Drug Regimens Help Patients Take Their Medicine

docs.abstract: Massachusetts General Hospital Drs David Shaywitz and Dennis Ausiello article on changes in drug regimens that can help people with AIDS and other diseases better manage them; research shows that AIDS patients who take drugs only intermittently develop HIV strains resistant to initial drugs; focus is on making dosing requirements easier and changing drug formulations; photo (M)

byline.original: By DAVID A. SHAYWITZ, M.D. and DENNIS A. AUSIELLO, M.D

docs.lead_paragraph: Even when smokers were told they had a genetic predisposition to smoking-related cancers, they were no more likely to quit than their counterparts who had no such tendency, researchers at the Duke University Medical Center say. The findings, focused on low-income people, appear this month in Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers and Prevention.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Duke University Medical Center, reporting in Cancer Epidemiology, Biomarkers and Prevention, find that black, low-income and poorly-educated smokers told they have genetic predisposition to smoking-related cancers are no more likely to quit than counterparts with no such tendency; drawing (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A new study may offer insight into the reasons that older women who exercise appear to have a lower risk of breast cancer. Researchers from the Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center in Seattle say they have found that in postmenopausal women, regular exercise seems to lower levels of estrogen in the blood.
docs.abstract: Researchers at Fred Hutchinson Cancer Research Center, addressing International Cancer Congress in Oslo, find that postmenopausal women who exercise regularly have lower levels of estrogen in blood, which lessens risk of breast cancer (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: A cynic wandering through the 17,000-person international AIDS conference here last week might have been tempted to point out that there were actually two conferences taking place under one roof, with remarkably contradictory messages. One was devoted to establishing the need for AIDS drugs in poor countries devastated by the epidemic. The other was devoted to coping with the endlessly mischievous, sometimes life-threatening complications of these same drugs.
docs.abstract: Dr Abigail Zuger Cases column on contradictory messages that arose at recent international AIDS conference in Barcelona, Spain; half of conference was devoted to establishing need for AIDS drugs in developing countries and other to coping with endless and sometimes life-threatening drug complications and side effects; recounts case of patient whose liver was on verge of failing and had to be taken off AIDS drugs (M)
